Friday, June 29, 2007























Step by step, researcher looks for sexuality clues
Can you tell whether someone's gay just by the way he or she walks? Or that  by watching a video of a child can you tell what his or her sexual orientation will be? A few university researchers think these things might be true, a sign, they believe, that sexuality is inborn rather than a choice.
FULL STORY




















NYC restaurants ditch trans fat cooking oils
New York City's ban on trans fat cooking oils in all city restaurants -- which goes into effect Sunday, July 1 -- seems to be going surprisingly smoothly.
FULL STORY






Superbug may strike 5 percent of patients
A dangerous, drug-resistant staph germ may be infecting as many as 5 percent of hospital and nursing home patients, according to a comprehensive study.
FULL STORY






Study: Echinacea may infection with cold virus
Echinacea may not only help reduce the symptoms of a cold but may help prevent infection with some cold viruses, U.S. researchers said Monday.
FULL STORY






Antidepressants' birth defects risk is small, study finds
Newborns face little risk of birth defects from antidepressants taken by many women early in pregnancy, say the two biggest studies of this controversial link.
FULL STORY
